item.title: Granblue Fantasy: Relink Has Sold Over 2 Million Units
item.content:encoded:
Today, Cygames revealed that the action JRPG Granblue Fantasy: Relink has surpassed two million units sold across all platforms (PC, PlayStation 4, and PlayStation 5 in the year and a half since launch. The team shared a brief message with the community to thank them for helping with this endeavor:

A Message from Tetsuya Fukuhara, General Director of Granblue Fantasy: Relink

What began as a Sky Realm adventure in mobile Granblue Fantasy hit home consoles and PC as Granblue Fantasy: Relink. Relink was an immense challenge for Cygames, but I feel that everyone on the development team approached the project with confidence and delivered a game that is brimming with our passion and dedication. After the game was released, the response from around the globe was bigger than we imagined, and we were delighted to have shared the world of Granblue Fantasy with so many people. On behalf of the entire development team, I would like to extend my heartfelt thanks to all the players. I've drawn a special illustration to commemorate 2 million copies sold, so I hope you like it!

A Message from Koichi Watanabe, President of Cygames

Granblue Fantasy: Relink has topped over 2 million copies sold in total worldwide sales. I would like to sincerely thank everyone around the world who played our game. Our company vision is to be the best in entertainment, which includes games, animation, comics, and many other entertainment mediums. The team spent a long time carefully crafting a title that would bring fun to many people regardless of where they are from. We hope everyone will continue to enjoy Relink while also engaging with other quality content that Cygames has to offer.

To celebrate the occasion, Cygames has enabled a 60% discount off Granblue Fantasy: Relink, the largest ever for the game. If you'd like to learn more about the game, head to our review.

item.title: AMD FSR 4 Confirmed to Be Coming to PS5 Pro in 2026; Big Chunks of RDNA 5 Are Being Designed Through Engineering Partnership with Sony
item.content:encoded:
It has been confirmed that AMD FSR 4, in its complete implementation, will be available to PS5 Pro developers starting next year. This isn't surprising, considering that Sony helped AMD develop the algorithm as part of Project Amethyst.

AMD FSR 4 will be available as an upgrade to the existing PlayStation Spectral Super Resolution (PSSR), which debuted with the PS5 Pro launch in late 2024. In an interview with Tom's Guide, Sony Lead System Architect Mark Cerny explained:

The algorithm they came up with could be implemented on current-generation hardware. So, the co-developed algorithm has already been released by AMD as part of FSR 4 on PC. And we're in the process of implementing it on PS5, and it will release next year on PS5 Pro. It's not a cut-down version of the algorithm. It's the full-fat version of the co-developed super resolution that we'll be releasing on PS5 Pro.

Commenting on the ongoing Project Amethyst partnership with AMD, Cerny added:

This is not for proprietary technology. This is really trying to move the industry forward. Obviously, we want to use these technologies on our consoles, but these technologies are available to any of AMD's customers freely. Big chunks of RDNA 5, or whatever AMD ends up calling it, are coming out of the engineering I am doing on the project. And again, this is coming out of trying to move things forward. There are no restrictions on the way any of it can be used. AMD is moving extremely quickly. What I'm trying to do is prepare for the next generation of consoles, so my time frame is multi-year here.

Indeed, the article shares a comment where both companies hint at an even tighter partnership than during the design of the PlayStation 5 or the PlayStation 5 Pro consoles.

This comes just days after AMD announced a multi-year partnership with Microsoft. However, that one seems focused on making various types of Xbox devices, including the upcoming ASUS ROG Xbox Ally handheld. In contrast, the Sony partnership is centered on machine learning powered upscaling advancements.

item.title: Death Stranding 2: On the Beach â€“ Use This DHV Magellan Trick to Restore Roads and Monorails Faster
item.content:encoded:
Besides completing deliveries and knitting back together a world that a cataclysmic event has torn apart, a big part of the Death Stranding 2: On the Beach experience is to collaborate with other players to build back the infrastructures that have been destroyed by the Death Stranding, and make it easier to complete deliveries and bring the world back together again under the Chiral Network. Doing so, however, can be a very time-consuming endeavor: to bring back roads and monorails, you will have to donate a lot of materials such as Chiral Crystals, Metals, and Ceramics, which can be sometimes hard to get, especially in the quantities required to bring these fundamental infrastructures back. Raiding enemy camps is a good way to collect some resources, but alas, it will still take some time to get everything you need.

There is a way, however, to restore roads and monorails in Death Stranding 2: On the Beach more quickly. To take advantage of this trick, however, you will have to play through the story until you complete Order 12 and unlock fast travel via the DHV Magellan. This will allow you to travel quickly to any zone deemed safe, including the cities and shelters you have connected to the Chiral Network in Mexico.

As you likely have noticed at this point in the game, in Death Stranding 2: On the Beach, you can take as much materials as you can carry from any city or shelter. As you are unlikely to return to Mexico after you are done with the beinning of the game, unless you want to max out the Connection Level, you can take the materials at your disposal in each city and shelter in Mexico, load them up on the DHV Magellan and bring them to Australia to put them to good use restoring roads and monorails without having to deal with a material shortage when crafting weapons and tools, as most of your in-game time is spent in Australia.

The process to put this trick into action is simple. Head into any city or shelter in Mexico, access the main terminal, enter the Fabrication and Management menu, and then pick the Claim Materials option. Select any material you want, load them up on your Floating Carrier or any vehicles you have in the vicinity, then head back into the DHV Magellan and add the Materials to its storage. Fast travel to the location nearest to the road or monorail you want to restore, claim the Materials back, load them up and then head to the infrastucture to donate them.

While this trick somewhat defeats the purpose of Death Stranding 2: On the Beach, it's still an excellent way to make one of the most tedious mechanics of the game more bearable. All the Materials you can get from Mexico won't be enough to restore every infrastrure in Australia, but they will provide you with a strong start that will make gathering the remaining materials needed far less time-consuming.
